anns.prefix: In the case of genotoxins, several DNA repair enzymes have been identified as target repair resistance mechanisms, including direct reversal of streptozotocin alkylation by AlkB and AGT (alkylguanine alkyltransferase) homologs (22), base excision of
anns.postfix: adducts by the DNA glycosylase YtkR2 (23, 24), nucleotide excision of DNA adducts of several intercalating agents, including daunorubicin (25), and putative replication-coupled repair of distamycin-DNA adducts (26).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: gene cluster in Streptomyces sahachiroi encodes a DNA glycosylase, AlkZ, which unhooks AZB-ICLs and provides cellular resistance against AZB toxicity (27, 28).
unhooking by AlkZ involves hydrolysis of the N-glycosidic bonds of the cross-linked deoxyguanosine residues, producing abasic (AP) sites that can be repaired by the base excision repair pathway (29).

anns.prefix: Most strikingly,
anns.postfix: genes, which are most prevalent in environmental microbes such as those from the phylum Actinobacteria (Fig. S1B), are highly enriched in BGCs.

anns.prefix: We found
anns.postfix: proteins in BGCs that produce a variety of verified and putative genotoxins, with approximately one-fifth of all AZL proteins located in BGCs predicted to produce a DNA alkylating agent.

anns.prefix: In a separate study, we recently found that the two paralogs present in
anns.postfix: and LLD clusters (TxnU2, TxnU4, LldU1, and LldU5) are self-resistance glycosylases for these compounds (56).

anns.prefix: In a separate study, we recently found that the two paralogs present in TXN and
anns.postfix: clusters (TxnU2, TxnU4, LldU1, and LldU5) are self-resistance glycosylases for these compounds (56).

anns.prefix: Consistent with their role in resistance, the

anns.prefix: In the case of genotoxins, several DNA repair enzymes have been identified as target repair resistance mechanisms, including direct reversal of streptozotocin alkylation by
anns.postfix: and AGT (alkylguanine alkyltransferase) homologs (22), base excision of yatakemycin-adenine adducts by the DNA glycosylase YtkR2 (23, 24), nucleotide excision of DNA adducts of several intercalating agents, including daunorubicin (25), and putative replication-coupled repair of distamycin-DNA adducts (26).

anns.prefix: The AZB gene cluster in Streptomyces sahachiroi encodes a DNA glycosylase,
anns.postfix: , which unhooks AZB-ICLs and provides cellular resistance against AZB toxicity (27, 28).

anns.postfix: involves hydrolysis of the N-glycosidic bonds of the cross-linked deoxyguanosine residues, producing abasic (AP) sites that can be repaired by the base excision repair pathway (29).
belongs to the relatively uncharacterized HTH_42 superfamily of proteins found in antibiotic-producing and pathogenic bacteria (28).

anns.prefix: A.R. is a scientific consultant for LifeMine Therapeutics, Inc. ABSTRACT Unique DNA repair enzymes that provide
anns.postfix: against therapeutically important, genotoxic natural products have been discovered in bacterial biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs).

anns.prefix: Despite their widespread existence in
anns.postfix: producers and pathogens, the roles of these proteins in production of other natural products are unknown.

anns.prefix: This work delineates two related families of DNA repair enzymes—one specific for complex alkyl-DNA lesions and involved in
anns.postfix: to antimicrobials and the other likely involved in protection against an array of genotoxins—and provides a framework for targeted discovery of new genotoxic compounds with therapeutic potential.

anns.prefix: Here, we characterized the genomic differences of the HTH_42 proteins found in 435 species of
anns.postfix: to develop additional insight into this new family of DNA repair proteins and applied this information in resistance-guided genome mining to characterize unknown BGCs or identify new genotoxins.

anns.prefix: Proteins similar to
anns.postfix: AlkZ (AlkZ-like, AZL) are highly variable in sequence and enriched in BGCs, many producing known genotoxic alkylating agents.

anns.prefix: In contrast,
anns.postfix: YcaQ-like (YQL) proteins are highly conserved in sequence and genetic neighborhood and are not associated with BGCs.

anns.prefix: We show that like
anns.postfix: YcaQ, two YQL enzymes from Actinobacteria have weaker substrate specificity than AZL proteins, suggesting a broader role of this subfamily of HTH_42 proteins outside antibiotic self-resistance in bacteria.

anns.prefix: The functions of many of these neighbors have not been elucidated in
anns.postfix: , but some are homologous to N-acetyltransferase, a two-component transcription factor/histidine kinase, and a DNA helicase (ComF) involved in transformation competence.

anns.prefix: DISCUSSION DISCUSSION Phylogenetic characterization of the HTH_42 superfamily proteins within
anns.postfix: reveals two distinct subfamilies, YQL and AZL (the latter of which contains the AZL2 clade).

anns.prefix: Phylogenetic characterization of the HTH_42 superfamily proteins within
anns.postfix: reveals two distinct subfamilies, YQL and AZL (the latter of which contains the AZL2 clade).

anns.prefix: Although the modest protection we observed from HedH4 overexpression in HED-challenged
anns.postfix: could be a result of the weak-expression promoter used, it also suggests that either the AP sites generated are poor substrates for the AP endonucleases present in E. coli or that HED-DNA adducts are substrates for an alternative repair pathway.

anns.prefix: More pertinent to HED biosynthesis, the producing organism
anns.postfix: contains two copies each of ExoIII- and EndoIV-like AP endonucleases that may have evolved to incise HED AP sites, although none are located in the hed BGC.

anns.prefix: Although the modest protection we observed from HedH4 overexpression in HED-challenged

anns.prefix: Although that pathway is unknown, the presence of a two-component transcription factor/kinase and ComF DNA helicase within the YQL neighborhood in
anns.postfix: also hints at a signaling network for DNA uptake (65–67).

anns.prefix: Similarly,
anns.postfix: YcaQ is localized in a four-gene operon involved in cell wall biosynthesis and transformation competence (31).

anns.prefix: Continued exploration of the gene neighborhoods of YQL and AZL beyond
anns.postfix: will reveal a deeper understanding of the cellular roles played by these enzymes.

anns.prefix: We sought to use this approach for the first time to hunt for BGCs that produce alkylating genotoxins, using prior knowledge of the DNA repair functions of
anns.postfix: AlkZ within the AZB cluster (28, 30, 31).

anns.prefix: In this study, we examined 435
anns.postfix: species for BGCs within which an AlkZ-related gene was located and found 68 uncharacterized clusters that are candidates for targeted elucidation of their products.

anns.prefix: This classification of YQL/AZL proteins in
anns.postfix: is an important first step in understanding their evolutionary connection to each other and to BGCs of different types and demonstrates that targeted resistance genome mining is a viable approach to discover novel genotoxins and resistance mechanisms from uncharacterized BGCs.
